qas.question: What laws do not specify an arrow of time?
The direction of the arrow of time is sometimes what?
Which law states that entropy must increase over time?
The violation of what implies that there should be a small counterbalancing time asymmetry?
The standard description of measurement in quantum mechanics is what?
In what directions do the laws of entropy allow light to go?
What does quantum mechanics determine about entropy?
What needs to be preserved according to quantum mechanics?
Which law says that CPT symmetry must increase over time?
In particle physics what should there be to preserve entropy?
What laws specify as an arrow of time?
The direction of the past is sometimes what?
Which law states that entropy must increase in the past?
The violation of what implies that there should be a small counterbalancing difection asymmetry?
What is the standard description of direction in quantum mechanics?

context: Time appears to have a direction—the past lies behind, fixed and immutable, while the future lies ahead and is not necessarily fixed. Yet for the most part <a0_0><b10_0>the laws of physics<b10_0/><a0_0/> do not specify an arrow of time, and allow any process to proceed <b5_0>both forward and in reverse<b5_0/>. This is generally a consequence of time being modeled by a parameter in the system being analyzed, where there is no "proper time": the direction of the arrow of time is sometimes <a1_0><b11_0>arbitrary<b11_0/><a1_0/>. Examples of this include <a2_0><b12_0>the <b8_0>Second law of thermodynamics<b12_0/><b8_0/>,<a2_0/> which states that entropy <b6_0>must increase over time<b6_0/> (see Entropy); the cosmological arrow of time, which points away from the Big Bang, CPT symmetry, and the radiative arrow of time, caused by light only traveling forwards in time (see light cone). In particle physics, the violation of <a3_0><b13_0>CP symmetry<b13_0/><a3_0/> implies that there should be <b9_0>a small counterbalancing time asymmetry<b9_0/> to preserve <b7_0>CPT symmetry<b7_0/> as stated above. The standard description of measurement in quantum mechanics is also <a4_0><b14_0>time asymmetric<b14_0/><a4_0/> (see Measurement in quantum mechanics).
